title: Elementalist Biome
description: The available biomes for the Elementalist game.

oneOf.description: A dense, warm, wet forest, typically found in tropical areas.
A warm, wet forest that loses its leaves in the dry season.
A warm, wet forest that loses some of its leaves in the dry season.
A dense, warm, wet forest with very large trees.
A forest that loses its leaves in the winter.
A forest of coniferous trees.
A cold forest of coniferous trees.
An area of land covered with trees.
An area of land covered with shrubs.
A grassy plain in tropical and subtropical regions, with few trees.
A large open area of country covered with grass, especially one used for grazing.
A vast, flat, treeless Arctic region of Europe, Asia, and North America in which the subsoil is permanently frozen.
A dry, barren area of land, especially one covered with sand, that is characteristically desolate, waterless, and without vegetation.
An area covered with low-growing or stunted trees.
An area of wet, spongy ground with soil composed mainly of decayed vegetable matter.
A swamp with fresh water.
A swamp with salt water.
An area of coastal grassland that is regularly flooded by seawater.
An area of land that is covered with a shallow layer of water during some or all of the year.
A large body of water surrounded by land.
A landform that forms from deposition of sediment carried by a river as the flow leaves its mouth and enters slower-moving or standing water.
A river that flows into the sea.
A river that flows into a lake or another river.
An area of low-lying ground adjacent to a river, formed mainly of river sediments and subject to flooding.
A river that flows through hilly or mountainous country.
A closed drainage basin that retains water and allows no outflow to other bodies of water such as rivers or oceans.
An island that is not part of a continent.
The expanse of salt water that covers most of the earth's surface and surrounds its landmasses.
The deepest part of the ocean.
The relatively shallow (200m) area of the sea floor surrounding the continents.
A ridge of rock in the sea formed by the growth and deposit of coral.
A large underwater area with a high density of kelp.
A slowly moving mass or river of ice formed by the accumulation and compaction of snow on mountains or near the poles.
A mass of glacial ice, more than 50,000 square kilometers (19,000 square miles).
Too poor to produce much or any vegetation.
Inside a building.
In, relating to, or characteristic of a city or town.
Prepared and used for raising crops.
Covered with trees or forests.
Land used for grazing and browsing animals.
